Committee of Supply – Head O (Ministry of Health)

Head O (cont) −

ElderShield

Dr Lam Pin Min (Sengkang West) : Mr Chairman, Sir, ElderShield is an insurance scheme introduced in 2002 to provide financial help to those who are unable to take care of themselves because of severe disabilities. Since the last revision in 2007, the basic ElderShield payout stands at $400 per month for 72 months. With medical inflation and the high cost of nursing care, this quantum is insufficient to cover the basic medical needs of most low- and middle-income families. Will the Ministry consider revising this amount in view of the escalating medical cost? Can the Ministry also give an update on the take-up rate for this scheme?

Page: 2131

MediShield for the Elderly

Mr David Ong (Jurong) : Mr Chairman, Sir, in our many helping hands approach supported by the 3Ms of healthcare financing and our family as the cornerstone of elderly care, the presence of MediShield has been a source of much comfort and support for Singaporeans. In the area of caring for our elderly sick, the financial strains can be debilitating. The strains almost nearly cut across all social classes particularly more acute for the low income and sandwich class. A person with stroke and in a comatose condition lying in an intensive care ward for 30 days can easily chalk up $30,000 on hospitalisation cost alone. Thus, even with the 3Ms and subsidised assistance, the financial strains can be crippling. Although I applaud the extension of the MediShield coverage to 90 years in this year's Budget, I believe we can do more.

The twilight years of a person's life are the period when they utilise the most healthcare. A person living long beyond the age of 80 would probably have stopped working for at least 15 years. Thus, it may be the case that they would have used up most of their savings accumulated in their working life. Their children may also have progressed to become senior citizens themselves. Hence, the burden of caring for them may cascade down to their grandchildren.

Presently, there are 11,100 Singaporeans aged 90 and above whom I shall call "Elite Seniors". It will be a benevolent gesture to honour our Elite Seniors for their contribution and sacrifices made for the country. Would it not make good sense to go that extra distance and complete the MediShield coverage for our Elite Seniors till the end of life? This will give our honourable Seniors the added peace of mind as they live to a ripe old age, knowing that they can be less of a financial burden to their children or grandchildren.

Can the Government work with its MediShield's private insurers to make extending MediShield coverage to end of life a reality? Can an assistance scheme for premiums be looked into for co-payment of a higher premium?

Sir, I would also like to ask the MOH to help promote and encourage MediShield coverage for women aged 65 and above. The number of working women in Singapore lags behind many countries. We have about 65% women working here versus about 80% in Norway. Hence, the number of women having little or no CPF is estimated to be easily about 30%. Correspondingly, a majority of the 170,000 women aged 65 and above will have no MediShield coverage. Sir, I would like to ask MOH if our current MediShield coverage is adequate, given the rise in medical and healthcare costs. Can the Ministry do more with its MediShield coverage for our Elite Seniors and senior women?

Increasing the MediShield Coverage

Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song (Non-Constituency Member) : Mr Chairman, MediShield is a Government-administered insurance scheme. It is meant to help cover the cost of major hospital bills. Unfortunately, some of those who need MediShield coverage the most, like babies with congenital problems and the very old, are often denied coverage. MediShield currently covers 92% of Singaporeans. Those who are not covered include some of the elderly, homemakers and others who have voluntarily opted out of MediShield. Some are not able to obtain MediShield coverage due to pre-existing conditions. I would like to ask what the Ministry is doing to help achieve a higher level of MediShield coverage for all Singaporeans. What is the Ministry's targeted level of MediShield coverage?

Page: 2132

Currently, newborns with congenital conditions are either denied MediShield coverage completely or have their conditions excluded from coverage. This does nothing to relieve the financial hardship that parents of these children may face. In order to ensure that these children are adequately covered under the MediShield, will the Ministry consider providing pregnant women an option to buy a MediShield rider to cover for any congenital problems or prematurity-related complications? This should naturally be done before any problems are diagnosed. It would be a one-off payment for the rider and it could actuarially be adjusted upwards for older women as they are at a higher risk of having babies with congenital problems or prematurity-related complications. This will provide the insurance coverage if the baby is later diagnosed with a problem, yet it would ensure a large enough risk pool to cover the potential payouts. Overall, this change should not require any increases in premiums.

As proposed during my Budget debate speech, will the Ministry consider doing away with the age cap of 90 years old for MediShield altogether? There are currently only about 11,000 Singaporeans aged above 90. We should be doing all we can to help this small group of seniors who have made it this far, instead of denying them the insurance coverage when they need it the most. Beyond age 90, many of them may have outlived their own children or siblings and have no direct relatives to support them.

I note some enhancements to MediShield coverage may require premium increases. However, based on the Minister's reply to my Parliamentary Question (PQ), between 2006 and 2010 MediShield collected an average of $131 million more in premiums each year than it paid out in claims. While I appreciate the need to set aside a portion of the premiums as reserves, can the Ministry relook at whether the premiums collected can be used to cover at least part of the increased coverage, instead of passing the additional cost entirely to policyholders? Currently MediShield premiums vary widely according to the members' age from $30 a year for those aged below 30, to $1,123 for those in their 80s. This imposes a heavier burden on older members, many of whom may be retired or have exhausted their Medisave. If premiums can be increased to cover the additional claims, can they be increased for working adults, instead of the elderly?

Medisave and MediShield

Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef (Marine Parade) : Mr Chairman, our 3M scheme is a good one. Medisave has since its inception been expanded to cover beyond hospitalisation expenses. These include its use in Chronic Disease Management Programme (CDMP), payment for certain chemotherapy and radiotherapy, dialysis, and so on. MediShield, on the other hand, is a medical insurance scheme.

I would like to ask MOH to consider increasing the Medisave from $400 to $500 per annum for the CDMP in view that (i) Singaporeans are having more chronic illnesses these days, especially with the rapidly ageing population; (ii) the push towards more ambulatory and outpatient care, which would mean patients may have to make more out-of-pocket payments; (iii) the use of new generation and non standard drugs for treatment may end up with a slightly higher cost for patients; and (iv) the increasing healthcare cost from market forces. There has been much feedback on the payment of the administrative fees for CDMP. Can this be waived, absorbed or reviewed?

Page: 2133

On MediShield, Sir, I have the following suggestions: first, can the upper age limit be extended considering that Singaporeans are living longer? On the average, for every eight-hour shift I do at the Emergency Department, there would be at least two patients who are aged 90 years or more. Can we also expand the repertoire of riders and companies available for choice, and, finally, similar to my call at last year's Committee of Supply (COS), can we extend MediShield for use in congenital diseases, as well as related familial screening, in a regulated way. Those affected need regular follow up with multiple procedures and aggressive interventions. For those with congenital problems that end up living into adulthood, multiple complications will surface again requiring intervention. Also, can we do more roadshows to encourage women to come forward and sign up for MediShield?

Free MediShield Coverage

Mr Gan Thiam Poh (Pasir Ris-Punggol) : Mr Chairman, I would like to request that the Ministry considers providing free MediShield coverage to the lowest 20th percentile of Singapore citizens whose per capita income is about $750 and below, and to all homemakers looking after children up to the age of 17. A serious illness can wipe out one's Medisave and cash savings. Yet many poor families do not have any catastrophic medical insurance as they are struggling to meet more urgent daily expenses. Homemakers, children and the elderly are particularly vulnerable as they do not have incomes. Housewives sacrifice their earning opportunities to care for their children and the elderly at home. Yet, day in day out, they are doing work which, if monetised, is worth thousands of dollars a year. In many single-income families, housewives tend to scrimp and save and overlook their own medical insurance. Senior citizens in the lowest income groups have to face many issues. If they are working, their pay may have already been cut as their job responsibilities are reduced. If they are already retired, they worry about making their savings stretch. Either way, insurance premiums would be higher and less affordable to them. Currently, the annual premiums for MediShield start from $33. I hope the Ministry would consider assisting them by helping to pay for their coverage.

Medisave of Elderly

Ms Tin Pei Ling (Marine Parade) : Mr Chairman, Sir, many, if not all, in this House understand the principle behind imposing a minimum sum criteria for Medisave is to ensure that we set aside enough savings to meet our future healthcare expenses. Imposing an annual cap on the amount that we can withdraw from Medisave is in line with this principle as well. It has also been emphasised to us that we ought to rely on our Medisave, then MediShield and, when all else fails, do we then rely on Medifund. However, seniors who have retired therefore no longer have the income to co-pay for their health expenses and those who are without family members are unable to tap on another person's Medisave Account and can only rely on their Medisave for their healthcare expenditure. However, some of these elderly persons have apparently been compelled to tap on Medifund while they still have sufficient monies in their Medisave.

I have met one such elderly gentleman at my Meet-The-People Session (MPS) and he has been asking to use his Medisave for his medical expenses. He is in his 70s, has a heart condition and regularly needs medical attention. He believes he has sufficient savings in his Medisave for his medical bills. He strongly believes that he should be self-reliant and cannot understand why his request has been repeatedly rejected. Understandably, his is a rare case. But his request stems from his belief in personal responsibility which is a worthwhile value to support. Hence, would the Ministry consider allowing seniors to have more autonomy such as allowing them to exhaust their Medisave before offering Medifund to them?

MediShield for Congenital Diseases

Dr Janil Puthucheary (Pasir Ris-Punggol) : Mr Chairman, I declare my interest as a paediatrician working in a restructured hospital. The issue of MediShield for children with congenital diseases has been brought up in this House in previous Parliaments as well as in this debate. I would just like to add my voice to the chorus. Sir, the problems faced by these children and their families are significant. But many of the diseases can be treated such that these children can lead long, healthy and normal lives.

The current regulatory framework lumps together all congenital diseases, when in truth there are a significant number of conditions that can be treated in a straightforward manner with a reasonable prediction of cure and a normal life, and a relatively short hospital stay. If part of the current policy position for excluding these children is that these children are expected to not survive, then the policy has not kept up with advances in medical science.

Let me offer some examples. A ventricular septal defect, a hole-in-the-heart, has about a 95% chance of complete cure and an expectation of a long and healthy life. In contrast, a child born with a hypoplastic left heart has the odds stacked against him. The current policy pushes these two together. Let me move to an alternative example. An adult, however, who suffers a significant heart attack has about a 80% chance of survival. In contrast, another adult who has a ruptured aortic aneurysm has less than 30% chance of getting out of hospital alive. Both of those conditions are currently claimable under MediShield. So, the policy pushes those two conditions together.

This subject has been brought up in the House previously, and from previous replies, the main concern is one of risk-pooling and the effect on premiums. This is true if one treats all congenital diseases as being equal, and I would suggest that the assumptions underlying that position are based on out-dated science and medical knowledge.

I would like to suggest that a couple be allowed to apply for MediShield for their unborn child. And as part of that application, there should be a requirement for high quality antenatal screening, which can detect most of these conditions in time for appropriate preparation and counselling, with the final decision about being allowed to have MediShield being made after the child has been born. These criteria need not be subjective and can be independently verified.

Would the Minister consider extending the use of MediShield to cover children with congenital disorders? Would the Ministry consider examining the position that categorises all congenital diseases together?

Medisave and Outpatient Charges

Dr Chia Shi-Lu (Tanjong Pagar) : Mr Chairman, Sir, I wish to declare my interest as a specialist practising in a Government restructured hospital.

Sir, the Chronic Disease Management Programme is an excellent initiative to improve affordability for patients with chronic diseases requiring long-term outpatient follow-up. It covers many conditions such as diabetes, hypertension, stroke and the like. This has recently been expanded to include dementia and bipolar disorder, and is yet another clear and welcome sign of intent by the Ministry that it will address mental health in the community.

I would like to ask MOH to consider liberalising the use of Medisave for outpatient use in certain other circumstances, notably paediatric, cardiological and cancer specialist care. The reason is that these medical services are typically provided by specialists in hospital-based specialist clinics and they require frequent and sometimes costly investigations, and often involve medications and treatments that are long term and may be expensive. Patients and their families who are already struggling with out-of-pocket medical expenses can be tempted to skimp on certain outpatient treatments to cut down on costs. By further liberalising usage of Medisave in such situations, we can encourage better patient compliance with respect to management of these diseases, thereby improving outcomes and reducing chronicity and disability. Alternatively, I hope that MOH can explore health insurance schemes for outpatient care, perhaps as a variation of the managed care systems that are available in the private medical sector.

I also wish to end by raising an additional point that has been frequently brought up by members of the public, my patients, residents and also, very recently, by Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef. As noted, patients with chronic diseases are required to pay a processing fee to settle each outpatient treatment at the public hospitals when using their Medisave Accounts. Many patients have given feedback that they are unhappy with this surcharge. While they can understand that there is an administrative cost involved, they also feel deep down that they are essentially being charged to use their own savings. The point is this: if these patients were more comfortable financially in the first instance, they would have preferred not to dip into their Medisave in the first place. Hence, I would like to respectfully request that MOH, perhaps, discuss this with its partners, the CPF Board and the National Computer Systems, to see whether there are ways that they can maybe reduce or even waive this processing fee, considering that in today's society, a lot of payments are made electronically as well, and I suppose this can be done fairly cost-efficiently.

Accessible and Affordable Primary Care

Assoc Prof Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim (Nee Soon) : Sir, as one grows older, it is reasonable to expect one to have multiple illnesses. I have met a few elderly constituents and their children who shared with me that they have to go to the different hospitals and specialist clinics in the management of their different illnesses. In doing so, they have to pay the different charges and spend more time travelling as they go for their appointments at these hospitals and clinics. A few have shared with me that at times, they receive repeated referrals in between the polyclinics and hospitals, making them confused and having to pay more. All these create a lot of inconvenience to the patients and their family members. The families feel that they end up paying more in the management of their illnesses. In addition, the children of these elders shared with me that they usually need to take many days of leave to accompany their parents to the different appointments at the different hospitals and clinics. They hope that the Health Ministry will be able to bring a few of these services closer to their homes, where they are able to manage their illnesses better. This will result in convenience and possibly more affordable healthcare.

Sir, as we increase the expenditure on healthcare, I feel that it is important that we also look at making primary care more accessible and affordable to Singaporeans. Wherever possible, we should model the processes to be as accessible and affordable as possible to Singaporeans. I would like to ask the Minister on his plans in providing more accessible and affordable primary care for Singaporeans.

Community Health for Older Estates

The Senior Minister of State, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Heng Chee How) : Mr Chairman, Sir, Singapore's population is ageing rapidly as more of our elderly live longer. In estates with a higher and fast-rising proportion of the elderly, one of the concerns is easy and affordable access to quality basic medical care, including the management of chronic diseases. Many elderly therefore ask for polyclinics to be built near their homes. I think that is a short form way of requesting for accessible, quality and affordable healthcare near their homes. Whampoa is one such estate.

The Ministry has improved the coverage of the former PCPS, now called the CHAS scheme, to tap the local GP network and to provide affordable care for the community. I understand that the Ministry is also examining the idea of building community health centres to complement the work of GP network. I would like to ask for an update on these initiatives and to what extent have they increased the effective availability of accessible, affordable basic medical care in the older estates. I would also like to ask what has been the ground experience of setting up such GP network and what difficulties have surfaced, and what will the Ministry do to intensify and scale up this capability building.

Strengthening of Primary Healthcare

Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef : Mr Chairman, with our ageing population and increasing incidence of chronic diseases, GPs are well positioned in our healthcare system to provide accessible, holistic and continuing care. The GPs' overall share of primary care patients is 81% compared to their share of chronic disease follow-ups which is only 55%. The GPs may be under-utilised in this aspect as patients attend polyclinics, emergency departments in hospitals and specialist outpatient clinics. These institutions thus tend to get overloaded. There is a need to strengthen and enhance the public's perception of GPs and primary care.

This can be done with: (1) MOH's call for every family to have one family physician or a GP; (2) setting up of community health centres (CHCs) in a common vicinity, tagged with support services such as radiology, laboratory and allied health services. There could even be visiting consultants from tertiary institutions who can do this but they, of course, need to be given dedicated time so that they can work with the CHCs' personnel; (3) enhancing GPs' qualifications, knowledge and training, with postgraduate degree and diploma as well as working closely with the College of General Practitioners; and (4) frequent interactions between GPs and specialists in tertiary care and even perhaps using video-conferencing to manage some of the more complex and difficult cases. This can certainly help to cut down the number of referrals to the emergency departments and tertiary hospitals to a minimum and keep it to real emergent problems, thus offloading the tertiary system and improving waiting times.

All this requires a changed mindset amongst GPs and also the public. The GPs must take the lead and take ownership of these changes as it is planned in the Primary Care MasterPlan.

Can I ask MOH to update us on the number of proposed CHCs and their potential locations? Are we on track with the recruitment of healthcare personnel to man these CHCs? And how are we doing on the recruitment of more GPs and dental practitioners onto the CHAS Scheme, because I think that this is an important scheme that will have an impact towards strengthening our primary care.

Palliative Care

Ms Ellen Lee (Sembawang) : Mr Chairman, the World Health Organization defines "palliative care" as "an approach that improves the quality of life of patients and their families facing the problem associated with life-threatening illness, through the prevention and relief of suffering by means of early identification and impeccable assessment and treatment of pain and other problems, physical, psychological and spiritual".

However, as a young nation, very few Singaporeans know what palliative care is, what hospice does and how its services can be enhanced to cope with the silver tsunami in Singapore. It is no longer a matter of providing end-of-life care but how to enhance the quality of life of a dying person, to maintain it, improve it through nursing, psychological support and supporting the family members on this journey.

Death should not be stigmatised as taboo or inauspicious as all of us will die eventually. Children should be taught about death, not to instil fear in them but to let them accept it as a natural process of living. End-of-life care is not the prerogative of the old or the sick or people with cancer. Young children and youths need end-of-life care too, although their needs are very different from people who are, say, 70 or 80 years old.

How can the needs of the patients and their family members be met? Do we have the manpower to provide for such a service? What is the current state of palliative care and how accepting is the public of having such a service provided in their midst? What is the Ministry's projection of the need for palliative care in the short and long term and what is being done to cater to this growing need? Will there be community outreach programmes?

Enabling Silver Enterprises

Ms Tin Pei Ling : The following cut has got nothing to do with health but I think it was redirected because it is under "ageing".

Sir, in this year's Budget, the Finance Minister has introduced several measures for the elderly. These measures are appropriate and timely. Our seniors have enabled Singapore to progress to where we are today and we owe a debt of gratitude to them and we should do our upmost best to help them age with comfort and dignity.

Page: 2138

Singapore also needs to prepare for an ageing population by putting in place the support framework and services for senior to live in our community. Besides national schemes, the Government is also fostering services from the ground-up. The community has also initiated projects aimed at enabling a better understanding of the needs of all elderly and developing new services to meet these needs. Notwithstanding these moves, the Government will do well to harness the private and people's sectors to help. In this way, we can broaden the search for new ideas and enlist entrepreneurs to speed up the process of discovering seniors' needs and coming up with ways to meet them.

Can we do more to foster silver enterprises that can provide new services to the elderly? The need for some of such services may not be that obvious today. But as our population ages, this will become increasingly critical. How do we help silver enterprises build up in time for the future?

The Finance Minister has also introduced the Special Employment Credit (SEC) for companies which employ workers who are older than 50 years old. I think this will help older workers to secure and hold on to jobs. Nevertheless, not all seniors want to work as employees in firms. Some may decide to become entrepreneurs to try to do something in their silver years. I know of some seniors who have already embarked on such an entrepreneurship journey. For instance, I know of a Miss Helen Lim who started Silver Spring. She is a passionate lady who wished to remain active and contribute meaningfully to the economy and the society. Just like we have the SEC, might we consider setting up a framework to support seniors who want to be self-employed or who still have aspirations to fulfil? This might suit a minority of seniors but can be a useful complement to SEC.

Other countries have ventured into this area of silver entrepreneurship. For example, there is an organisation in the United Kingdom called the Prince's Initiative for Mature Enterprise (PRIME), founded by Prince Charles, which helps people over the age of 50 set up business for themselves. PRIME offers free information, workshops and business networking events. Some have argued that since Government is injecting $1.1 billion into commercially-run entities to run the BSEP over the next 10 years, why not simply nationalise public transport services instead? Our current model leaves the operations of trains and buses to commercial entities, as we believe the long-term public interest is best served this way. The profit incentive drives the operators towards higher efficiency and productivity, which keeps costs as low as possible. These productivity gains and cost savings are then passed on to commuters in the form of lower fare increases, as we have seen in our system. Otherwise, if the system is inefficiently-run, the public will ultimately pay for the higher operating costs, either through higher fares, or greater Government subsidies.

If we look at comparable examples around the world, we find that, in general, the most efficiently-run public transport services are provided by commercially-driven entities, such as the MTR in Hong Kong. And, increasingly, cities like Melbourne have also privatised their public transport industry to improve efficiency and productivity. The advantage of privatisation is actually well documented in the experience of London Buses. Let me share this with Members. London Buses was privatised in 1985. Between 1985 and 1996, the price per vehicle kilometre dropped 45%, while costs per passenger trip fell by nearly a third. This is even as ridership and reliability of the system both increased. Private contracting led to lower costs and about 10 years on from when the bus reforms were first introduced in 1985, London saw a 70% decrease in subsidies.

Even as we use commercial entities to run operations, it is important for Government to take control in key areas – to plan for rail lines and bus routes, to ensure a firm regulatory mechanism for fares, to specify service levels for rail and bus service, and to decide on timely capacity injection to meet ridership growth. We amended the Road Traffic Act in 2010, passed it in Parliament, to implement a new rail financing framework. Previously, the Government undertook the planning and development of our rail network, while the operator owned and operated rail operating assets. One of the key features of the new rail framework is that the Government will take over the ownership of operating assets and make the decisions on the timing of asset procurement and capacity enhancement. This enables us to ensure that sufficient capacity is brought in to meet projected ridership growth in a timely fashion. The new financing framework also facilitates greater contestability within the rail sector, spurring the operators to deliver better service levels.

By widening the price differential between low-emission models and high-emission ones, the scheme will help to accelerate the switch towards low-emission cars.
